Graphical abstract As a support for cobalt Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalyst, graphene needs to be pretreated to modify its surface properties for desired catalytic performance. Graphene was pretreated by thermal reflux using 20–60 % nitric acid. The pretreated graphene and catalysts were characterized with TPR, TEM, SEM, XRD, XPS and Raman spectroscopy to study the effect of treatment on microstructures of the materials. This work showed that cobalt metal uniformly dispersed on graphene, and with increasing pretreating acid concentration, surface defects increased and the cobalt particle size decreased, suggesting alleviated agglomeration of cobalt particles on graphene. Pretreating improved the reduction of the catalyst due to the increased defect sites, improved support-metal interaction and cobalt dispersion. Pretreated catalyst yielded better activity, higher C5+, but lower methane selectivity than unpretreated catalyst. Therefore, acid pretreatment of graphene can be an effective approach to modify the microstructure of the material, and can thus enhance the performance of the prepared catalyst. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Graphene Acid pretreatment Supported cobalt catalyst Coal-to-liquids Gas-to-liquids 1 Introduction Major energy needs still rely on traditional fossil fuels, such as coal, crude oil and natural gas [1,2]. Due to the limited reserve of crude oil and the pollution from combustion of fossil fuels, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS), which produces ultra-clean liquid fuels, has received increasing attention for decades [3]. An FT process is virtually a polymerization reaction that converts syngas, i.e., mixture of CO and H2 from biomass, coal or natural gas, to hydrocarbon fuels or valuable chemicals. FT catalyst plays an important role in the synthesis gas conversion process [4,5]. Typical active components of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalyst are Co, Fe, Ni or Ru [6], but only Fe and Co are practically used in commercial FT processes considering the cost of the metal. Supported cobalt FT catalyst is a preferred commercial catalyst over iron due to its low water-gas shifting activity, high long-chain hydrocarbon selectivity and high stability [7]. For Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, the microstructure and surface properties of the support, the dispersion of the metal can greatly affect the activity and selectivity of the catalyst [8]. Cobalt-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalyst supported on conventional oxides such as Al2O3 and SiO2 have been extensively studied [9–11]. Due to the overly strong interaction between the cobalt and the oxide support, cobalt can sometimes form a hard to reduce compounds (CoAl2O4, Co2SiO4), therefore deteriorating the efficacy of the active metal for syngas conversion. At the same time, carbon materials such as carbon nanotubes (CNT), nanofibers, carbon spheres, mesoporous carbons and activated carbon have been studied as FT catalyst support due to their superior mechanical strength, thermal stability, mesoporous structure and inertness [12–15]. Trepanier et al. investigated the effect of acid pretreatment on carbon nanotube-supported cobalt-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalysts [16]. They treated the carbon nanotubes with 30 % HNO3 at 25 and 100℃ for 14 h, separately, then impregnated 10 wt% cobalt on the treated and untreated carbon nanotubes. They found that after 30 % HNO3 treatment at 25℃ and 100℃, the specific surface area increased by 18 % and 25 %, respectively. The cobalt metal particle size decreased and the dispersion improved. Furthermore, the activity of the catalyst increased while the product slate shifted to lower molecular weight hydrocarbons. Vosoughi et al. studied the effect of different nitric acid concentrations on the structural properties, metal dispersion, crystallite size, defects on material surface, and the reduction property of the 15 wt% Co/CNT catalyst sample [17]. They found that pretreating with 70 % HNO3 improved physicochemical properties of the catalyst, and increased the hydrocarbon yield by 35 %. However, both the activity and the product selectivity of the carbon nanotube- supported catalyst were influenced by the deposition location of the active metal, and the catalyst was prone to sintering, when the metal particles were deposited outside of the tube [18]. In addition, the performance of the catalyst was related to the diameter of the carbon nanotubes [19]. These interesting finings prompted the great interest from the academic community to study the non-traditional materials as catalyst support. Graphene is a single-layer honeycomb-like material, composed of sp2 hybridized carbon atom. Due to its special monoatomic layered structure, superior mechanical, thermal, electrochemical and optical properties, the material can potentially be employed in energy storage, electronics and some other areas [20]. Graphene also shows excellent properties of superior specific surface area, thermal conductivity, chemical stability and mechanical strength, and thus can be properly utilized as catalyst support. Its unique microstructure suitable for potential catalytic application have attracted great interest in heterogeneous catalysis research [21]. However, a key issue for using graphene as catalyst carrier is to modify the hydrophobicity and inertness of the nano-material, thus to optimize the carrier-metal interaction for desired catalytic performance [21,22]. One way to improve catalytic properties of the material is to pretreat it by acid thermal reflux [23]. Saba Karimi et al. prepared Co-based catalysts by thermal reflux pretreating the graphene nano-sheets (GNS) and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) using 30 % HNO3 at 120℃. Their found that the particle size of the used Co/GNS catalyst increased from 6 to 6.8 nm, while the Co/CNT catalyst increased from 7.5–9.5 nm after 480 h of FT reaction. CO conversion of the Co/GNS catalyzed FT reaction was 12 % higher than that over the Co/CNTs catalyst [24,25]. Taghavi et al. pretreated graphene nano-sheet with nitric acid to adjust the interaction between the support and the metal particles for an FT catalyst [26]. They proposed that the formation of graphene surface functioning groups not only reduce the sintering of cobalt crystalline, but also accelerate the hydrogen spillover in the reduction process. This thus improves the dispersion, reduction and stability of the catalyst. Pretreatment of graphene plays an important role in enhancing its hydrophilicity and the metal-support interaction. Optimization of the pretreatment conditions of the material can greatly improve the performance of graphene-supported catalysts [27–29]. In our previous studies, various graphene supported cobalt catalysts were prepared for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis by hydrothermal synthesis in different solvents [30]. Activity evaluation results overs those catalysts showed that the catalyst prepared with ethanol generates better thermal resistance, higher carbon monoxide conversion and C5+ selectivity than the sample prepared with water as solvent. In this work, graphene-supported cobalt FT catalysts pretreated with different concentrations of nitric acid were systematically studied to further investigate the efficacy of graphene to be used in FT reaction. To the best of our knowledge, effect of nitric acid concentration on the microstructural properties of graphene and the performance of graphene-supported cobalt FT catalysts has yet to be studied so far. In this research work, pretreatment was conducted by thermal reflux using 20–60 % nitric acid, and then the samples were characterized with TPR, TEM, SEM, XRD, XPS and Raman spectroscopy to study the effect of surface treatment on material microstructural properties of the cobalt FT catalyst. Then all the catalyst samples, with and with no pretreatment, were tested in a fixed-bed reactor to find out the influence of the pretreating acid on catalytic performance of the catalyst samples. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material Graphene (SE1233) was purchased from Changzhou Sixth Element Materials Technology Co., Ltd. Nitric acid and Co(NO3)2·6H2O were from Beijing Chemical Plant and Aladdin Chemical Company, respectively. Cylinder gases, H2 (99.999 %), CO(99.9 %)and N2 (99.999 %) were purchased from Beijing AP BAIF Gas Industry. 2.2 Support pretreatment Pretreatment was conducted by mixing 10 g of graphene as received with 400 mL different concentrations of nitric acid solution in a round-bottom flask. Reflux the material with acid at 120℃ for 8 h, and cool it to room temperature. Then filter and wash the slurry mixture multiple times with deionized water to a neutral pH level. Dry the sample at 120 ℃ for 24 h to obtain the pretreated graphene base material G(xHNO3), where x is the concentration of pretreating nitric acid at 20 %, 30 %, 40 % or 60 %. 2.3 Catalyst preparation To prepare a graphene-supported cobalt FT catalyst, dissolve a prespecified amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O in deionized water and load cobalt to graphene by incipient wetness impregnation. Let the catalyst sample settled for 24 h and dry it at 120℃ for another 24 h. Then calcine the sample at 375℃ for 6 h under nitrogen atmosphere. The catalysts prepared with pretreated graphene using different concentrations of nitric acid are denoted as Co/G(xHNO3), where x stands for the concentration of nitric acid. In the meantime, a catalyst supported on untreated graphene was prepared as a base control sample designated as Co/G. 2.4 Catalyst characterization 2.4.1 Nitrogen physical adsorption-desorption The specific surface area, the pore volume, and the pore size of the graphene sample and the graphene-supported catalyst samples were characterized with BELSORP-max physical adsorption instrument (MicrotracBEL, Corp.). Prior to the characterization procedure, degas the sample at 300℃ for 6 h to drive off the impurities and moisture. The instrument was operated in -196℃ liquid nitrogen to obtain the adsorption-desorption isotherms [31,32]. 2.4.2 Temperature programmed reduction with H2 gas (H2-TPR) Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was conducted on a BELCAT-II (MicrotracBEL, Corp.) chemisorption instrument, equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Prepare the BET sample in flowing argon at 300℃ and cool it to 50℃ before the TPR test. Similar to the reduction process in a fixed-bed reactor, a diluted hydrogen (10 vol% in argon) was used at 30 mL/min in the procedure. Then the sample was heated from 50 to 800℃ at a heating rate of 10℃/min per our previous studies [30,31]. 2.4.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The XRD measurement was performed on a Shimadzu 7000 X-ray diffractometer with a Cu-Ka radiation source. Scanning angle ranged from 10 to 80° and the scanning speed was at 4°/min. The average particle size of the Co3O4 crystallites in the catalyst was calculated based on the characteristic peak data at 36.8° (2θ) using Scherrer equation [33] as follows: (1) d = 0.89λ/βcosθ×(180°)/π Where λ is the wavelength of the diffraction line, and β is the diffraction peak half width of the Co3O4 crystallite at 36.8° [30]. The crystallite size of the metallic cobalt is calculated using the following equation [34]. (2) d(Codegr) = 0.75d(Co3O4) 2.4.4 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy is one of the most useful, quick and non-destructive high- resolution techniques for characterization of carbon materials. Degree of graphitization, carbon atom disorder and surface defects can be easily detected with Raman spectroscopy [35]. Use an excitation wavelength of 514.5 nm, power of 50 mW and slit width of 50 μm in the procedure. 2.4.5 Scanning and transmission electron microscopes (SEM/TEM) Morphology of the support and the catalysts were obtained on XL 30 S-FEG (FEM Corporation.) scanning electron microscope (SEM) operated at 20 KV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image was obtained on JEM-2100 Plus Electron Microscope. Prior to the procedure, grind the material with a mortar and pestle, and disperse the sample in absolute alcohol. To obtain a uniformly dispersed TEM sample, put it in an ultrasonic oscillator before drop a small amount of suspended slurry on a copper grid to obtain a thin carbon film for the TEM measurement. 2.4.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) This part of the characterization was carried out on an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Thermo Fischer, ESCALAB 250Xi) with a monochromatic Al Ka X-ray source (1253.6 eV). Operate it at a chamber vacuum of 8 × 10−10 Pa, voltage of 12.5 kV and filament current of 16 mA and use signal accumulation of 10 cycles, passing-energy of 40 eV and a step length of 0.1 eV in the procedure. 2.4.7 Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) Although the metal loading was predesigned before the preparation of the catalyst sample, actual cobalt content in prepared catalyst sample was experimentally obtained with Jarrel-ASH, ICAP-9000 inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). All the results reported in this study were based on actual experimentally measured data of the active cobalt metal contents. 2.5 Catalytic performance evaluation test The catalysts were evaluated in a stainless steel fixed-bed tubular reactor (12 mm diameter) to obtain the activity and selectivity information. In catalyst reduction process with 10 vol% H2 in N2, heat the reactor from room temperature to 400℃ at a heating rate of 2.5 °C/min. Let the in-situ reduction last for 10 h, then switch the feeding reduction gas to synthesis gas (H2: CO = 2:1) to initiate the FT reaction at 220℃, 2.5 MPa and 3 SL h−1 g−1cat. The flow rates of the feeding syngas were regulated with a set of mass flow controllers(Brooks F29152−008; 0−500 sccm capacity)and the reaction pressure was controlled with a back-pressure regulator (BPR) [30]. Gas product from the reactor was analyzed with an on-line quick gas chromatograph (Agilent 490 Micro Gas Chromatograph) equipped with four separate GC modules. Detailed GC columns data were given in the supplementary information (Table S1). CO conversion (XCO) and product selectivity (for methane as SCH4, CO2 as SCO2, C5+ hydrocarbon as SC5+ and other hydrocarbons as SCr) were calculated using the following equations: (3) X C O = n c o , i n - n c o , o u t n c o , i n × 100 % (4) S C H 4 = n C H 4 , o u t n c o , i n - n c o , o u t × 100 % (5) S C O 2 = n C O 2 , o u t n c o , i n - n c o , o u t × 100 % (6) S C r ( r = 2,3 , 4 ) = r × n c r , o u t n c o , i n - n c o , o u t - n C O 2 , o u t × 100 % (7) SC5+ = 1-SCH4 -SC2-SC3-SC4 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The physical structural properties of graphene and graphene-supported catalyst samples were obtained from nitrogen adsorption-desorption procedure, as summarized in Table 1 . The specific surface area of the sample was determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the pore structure information was obtained by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method [31]. As shown in Table 1, BET results indicated that the specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the original unpretreated graphene were relatively large at 456.85 m2/g, 3.39 cm3/g and 26.71 nm, respectively. It suggests that graphene can be a good support material candidate for a high loading cobalt catalyst. When cobalt metal was added to the support material, both BET and pore volume were dramatically lowered, which may be attributed to the pore blockage by the metal particles, as suggested by Trepnier et al. [16] or the "dilution effect" of the cobalt oxide on carbon [23,36]. As the pretreating acid concentration increased, pore volume and BET surface area slightly decreased, while the metal loading and pore diameter grew. Though cobalt loading was prespecified before the preparation step, not all cobalt in the titration solution can be fully loaded to the support material in the incipient wetness impregnation step. Surface pretreatment with nitric acid on the graphene can modify the surface and pore structural properties of the graphene carrier, which may affect the actual loading of cobalt particles. Surface defects and hydrophobicity of the pretreated material also affected the amount of cobalt to be loaded onto the pretreated graphene support. The resulted cobalt loading can in turn affect other properties of the prepared catalyst. The Co/G (60 % HNO3) catalyst showed the smallest specific surface area and the smallest pore volume among all samples concerned. Some of these results appeared differently from those catalyst prepared on traditional alumina or silica materials due to the special 2-D structure of graphene. It is likely that higher acid concentration caused more pore structural collapse and formed larger pores, thus more cobalt can be deposited on these larger pores on suitably modified surface of the treated graphene support. Nitrogen isothermal physical adsorption-desorption curves of Co/G, Co/G (20 % HNO3), Co/G (30 % HNO3), Co/G (40 % HNO3), Co/G (60 % HNO3) catalysts were shown in Fig.1 . At relative pressure of P/Po ≥ 0.4, all the catalysts showed a hysteresis loop due to the capillary condensation effect, which conforms to the characteristic type Ⅳ isothermal adsorption/desorption curve defined by IUPAC [37]. This evidenced the mesoporous structures of the catalyst pores [38]. Reduction property of the catalyst was characterized using H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR). As shown in Fig. 2 , all catalysts showed two reduction steps from 300 to 600℃. The first peak related to the conversion from Co3O4 to CoO at 350−400℃, and the other peak for CoO to Co at 527−576℃. The H2-TPR data indicated that the reduction temperature gradually shifted to the left, suggesting increasing concentration of pretreating acid can enhance the reduction of the catalyst. The higher the pretreating acid concentration was used, the better reduction property can be achieved for the pretreated catalysts. It is likely that after treatment with a relatively high concentration of nitric acid, major part of the structure of graphene were destroyed and more defects were generated, thus promoting the hydrogen adsorption on active cobalt particles. As suggested by Taghavi et al. that the surface treatment resulted in more favorable defects and thus promoted the hydrogen spillover on these defect sites in catalyst reduction process [26]. Fig. 3 showed the XRD patterns of catalysts, and it revealed that the catalysts supported on graphene pretreated with different concentrations of nitric acid yields the same phase composition, i.e., graphite carbon, Co3O4 and CoO. As shown in Fig. 3, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 26.3°, 44.4° and 78.8°were typical of graphite (0 0 2), (1 0 1) and (1 1 0) lattice planes, respectively (PDF #41−1487). As the pretreating acid concentration increased, the (1 0 1) diffraction peak intensity of the graphene significantly weakened. This explained the increased number of defects on the graphene surface. The diffraction peak of Co3O4 at 2θ = 31.3°, 36.8°, 59.4° and 65.4° correspond to the (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (5 1 1) and (4 4 0) lattice planes, respectively (PDF#43−1003). The diffraction peak of CoO at 2θ = 42.4° corresponded to the (200) crystal plane (PDF#43−1004). Table 2 showed and compared cobalt particle size information from both TEM picture and the calculated data out of XRD result. Cobalt (Co or Co3O4) particle size decreased gradually as the pretreating acid concentration increased, proving the metal dispersion improvement by the acid pretreatment. In summary, the XRD data of all pretreated graphene-supported catalysts showed very similar patterns to each other, while the diffraction patterns of graphitic carbon appeared very different from that of cobalt oxide. It suggested that the difference in nitric acid concentration yield little effect on the phase composition, but it did affect the degree of graphitization of carbon and the crystalline size. Cobalt particle size decreased as the higher pretreating acid concentration was used, thus promoted the dispersion of the active metal on the surface of the support. Fig. 4 shows the Raman spectra of the catalysts supported on nitric acid pretreated graphene. Two characteristic peaks of graphene appeared at 1350 cm−1 and 1596 cm−1 in Raman spectra, i.e., the D peak and the G peak, respectively. The G peak corresponded to the intra-plane stretching vibration of the sp2 carbon atom, which evidenced a graphitic structure related to degree of order of the C atom. The D peak is a disordered vibration peak, representing the surface defect and the degree of disorder of graphene carbon [39]. From the same Raman data, the wavenumber and intensity of the d- and G-band of graphene and catalysts were summarized in Table 3 . The area ratio of d-peak to G-peak was denoted as ID/IG, representing the number of surface defects and degree of disorder of carbon atoms [40]. This ratio of ID/IG is close to zero for a highly ordered structure, such as pyrolitic graphite [43]. Comparing the ID/IG value of the unpretreated graphene with the Co/G(xHNO3) catalysts (x is the concentration of nitric acid) showed that impregnation of cobalt led to the can increase the ID/IG ratio. This proved that cobalt-based catalysts supported on graphene showed a significant number of defects and high degree of carbon disorder on the surface of the material. The ID/IG ratios of Co/G (base sample), Co/G (20 % HNO3), Co/G (30 % HNO3), Co/G (40 % HNO3) and Co/G (60 % HNO3) were 1.55, 1.83, 1.85, 1.99 and 2.02, respectively, suggesting that the number of defects on graphene surface increased as the concentration of pretreating nitric acid increased. Increased number of surface defects offered more adsorption sites for the cobalt metal particles and resulted in better cobalt particle dispersion. Scanning electron microscopy results of cobalt-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalysts prepared from different nitric acid-treated graphene supports were shown in Fig. 5 . It indicated that the morphology of the catalyst samples (b, c, d, e, f) and graphene (a) are significantly different from each other. SEM of graphene sample showed a clean surface and layered structure. Cobalt oxide particles on graphene can be easily spotted in the SEM picture of catalyst samples. Large circular cobalt particles (400 nm) appear unevenly dispersed on the surface of the graphene supported cobalt catalyst without nitric acid treatment. Increase in pretreating nitric acid concentrations enhanced the cobalt particles dispersion and alleviated the agglomeration of cobalt particles. It clearly suggested that the higher the pretreating acid was used, the better metal dispersion was achieved for these catalysts. The sample pretreated with 60 % nitric acid yielded the most uniform dispersion and the smallest active metal particle size among all the catalysts concerned. Fig. 6 is the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) diagram of the catalyst prepared by the treatment of graphene carrier with different concentrations of nitric acid. Fig. 6(a) revealed more folding on the surface and higher thickness from the pristine graphene material than all the other samples. Picture from samples (b) through (f) showed that the folding and stacking on the graphene surface significantly weakened when pretreated with acid. Irregular black spots on the graphene surface represented the Co3O4 crystalline for all catalysts. Some degree of agglomeration of metal particles appeared on the surface of the catalyst samples. Cobalt particles distributed more uniformly on surface of the pretreated samples than unpretreated sample. Dispersion of the cobalt particles was enhanced with increasing concentration of the pretreating acid. Cobalt particle size distribution histogram was obtained with Nano Measurer Analysis instrument. As shown in supplementary Figure S1, the crystalline grain size shown in TEM was consistent with the XRD result. The higher the pretreating acid concentration was used, the narrower the particles size distribution of cobalt appeared in this Fig. S1. This can be attributed to the promoting of the support-metal interaction. This in turn can generate narrower size distribution than unpretreated support [24,41]. As confirmed from the Raman results, the number of defects on the graphene surface grew as the acid concentration increased. These defects are preferred nucleation sites that are beneficial for anchoring of cobalt particles on the surface of graphene. Due to the enhanced support-metal interaction by these surface defects, the size distribution of cobalt particles also decreased with the help of the surface defects. The dispersion and reduction properties of the cobalt catalyst are important aspects for desired Fischer-Tropsch synthesis reaction activity. TEM and SEM pictures showed that with increasing nitric acid concentration, agglomeration of the cobalt particles on the surface of graphene weakened. Taghavi suggested that defects on the surface of graphene can reduce the fluidity of metal particles and reduce their tendency to agglomerate [27]. TEM and SEM pictures clearly proved that higher concentration of nitric acid yielded more surface defects on graphene surface. Similar to those XRD and TPR results, TEM pictures reveals that pretreating the materials can produce better metal dispersion and reduction properties of the catalyst. It could in turn lead to a better catalytic activity in an FT reaction. XPS is one of the important characterization approaches for obtaining the composition and chemical state of the element on catalyst surface. Fig. 7 a showed the XPS survey scan spectra result from the five catalyst samples concerned in this study. This XPS data showed that three elements, i.e. C, Co and O, existed in the sample. The Co2p XPS spectrum of the catalyst was shown in Fig. 7(b). Vibration peaks corresponding to Co2+ and Co3+ at bonding energies of 779 and 795 eV, respectively, confirmed that cobalt was mainly in the forms of Co3O4 and CoO, which was also confirmed from our XRD results. As the concentration of pretreating nitric acid increased, the Co2p3/2 peak of the catalyst shifted toward the higher bonding energy side, while the width of the half-peak slightly increased. It also showed that the higher nitric acid concentration led to smaller cobalt particles and better dispersion, proving the improved metal-support interaction was resulted from acid pretreatment. As shown in Fig. 7a, the C1 s peak at bonding energies of 284, 286 and 288 eV, corresponds to three oxygen-bearing groups, CC, CO and CO, respectively [42,43]. Repartition of the C1 s peak into three sub-areas and the percentage of each of the three sub-areas can be calculated to obtain the relative content of CC, CO or CO species, respectively, as given in Table 4 . The data in the table showed that the contents of the two oxygen-bearing groups in the catalyst changed very slightly when using different concentrations of pretreating acid. Also as Wei et al. suggested that content of oxygen-bearing groups exert little effect on the performance of the catalyst [44]. Table 5 showed that increasing pretreating acid concentration yielded increasing Co to carbon ratio, as Khodakov suggested that this increased surface Co/C ratio proved the improved dispersion of the cobalt metal on support material of graphene [45]. 3.2 Performance of the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalyst The catalytic performance evaluation was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor for 70 h at 220℃, 2.5 MPa, H2:CO = 2. Tail gas from the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis reactor was analyzed with an on-line quick GC to identify the composition of the gas phase product to study the catalyst activity and product selectivity. Table 6 listed the CO conversion of the catalyst and the product selectivity after 40 h of continuous Fischer-Tropsch synthesis reaction. To better understand the effect of nitric acid treatment on the performance of catalysts, unpretreated graphene-supported cobalt-based catalyst as a control sample was also tested in the FT reactor. As shown in Table 6, CO conversion rates over the five catalysts treated with 0, 20, 30, 40, 60 % of acid were 18.5 %, 20.2 %, 24.8 %, 28.4 %, and 37.0 %, respectively. Increasing the pretreating nitric acid concentration from 0, 20, 30, 40 and 60 % improved CO conversion proportionally. CO conversion was more than doubled when 60 % acid was used to pretreat the graphene support. This strongly proved the beneficial effect of acid pretreating on the activity of the FT catalyst. Fig. 8 showed the carbon monoxide conversion vs. time-on-stream over the Co/G, Co/G (20 % HNO3), Co/G (30 % HNO3), Co/G (40 % HNO3) and Co/G (60 % HNO3) catalysts. The data showed different patterns of activity and stability of the catalysts in 70 h of testing. It revealed that the nitric acid treated graphene-supported cobalt catalyst was more stable than catalyst prepared from unpretreated support material. The higher the nitric acid concentration was used, the better stability can be obtained. This was likely attributed to the increased number of defects and the improved interaction between the support and the cobalt metal, which in turn enhanced the adsorption of the cobalt particles on the surface of the support [18,25]. In the supplementary information, the hydrocarbon product selectivity at the stabilized conversion level (40 h) was shown in Figure S2. Table 6 summarized the CO activity, and selectivity of CO2, CH4, C2-C4 and C5+ over the catalyst samples concerned. Obviously, as the concentration of nitric acid increased, the selectivity of methane increased and the selectivity of C5+ decreased, suggesting that higher pretreating acid concentration was more favorable to shorter chain hydrocarbon production. In addition, nitric acid pretreatment can also affect the water-gas shift activity, and thus raise the CO2 selectivity. Fig. 9 through 11 showed the effect of pretreating condition on olefin to paraffin ratio from the FT reaction. It indicated that pretreating the catalyst with 60 % acid generated the highest ethylene, but the lowest propylene and butylene. Therefore, high acid concentration can significantly enhance the production of ethylene, but not the C3 and C4 olefins. All samples treated with 20–40 % acid yielded similar ethylene to ethane ratios to each other. For propylene to propane ratio, only 40 % acid generated a higher value than the other samples (Figs. 10 , 11 ). In summary, pretreating of graphene can be helpful for better microstructural properties of the material to be used as catalyst support for FT reactions. Surface pretreatment of the graphene material with different concentrations of nitric acid modified the surface microstructures and pore properties of the material. Enhancement of the surface and pore properties of the support can in turn exert a great influence on the activity of and the selectivity of the prepared catalyst. 4 Conclusions This work revealed that surface pretreating of graphene can generate significant effect on the microstructure of the material, and thus enhance the properties of the cobalt catalyst supported on the material. Nitric acid pretreatment will positively enhance the surface area, pore size and pore volume properties of the graphene material. Mesoporous structure was evidenced in the pretreated material, as proven from the BET data. XRD and XPS results revealed that major phase of cobalt in these pretreated catalysts are CoO and Co3O4, but the acid concentration exerted little effect on the composition of the metal oxides. TEM and SEM results proved that acid pretreating can alleviate the agglomeration of the cobalt particles on the catalyst surface and improve the dispersion of the metal on the surface of graphene. XRD and H2-TPR data also indicated that high acid concentration improved the reducibility of the catalyst due to the increased defect sites, improved support-metal interaction and enhanced cobalt metal dispersion. This in turn resulted in the improved reaction activity for FT process. Pretreatment of the graphene support material with the 60 % nitric acid can significantly increase the CO conversion from 18 to 37 %. The pretreated catalyst can yield lower methane but higher C5+ selectivity than that from the catalyst supported on unpretreated graphene. Therefore, acid pretreatment of graphene can be an effective approach to modify the microstructure of the material, and thus enhance the performance of cobalt-based Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalyst. coredata.dc:description: As a support for cobalt Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalyst, graphene needs to be pretreated to modify its surface properties for desired catalytic performance. Graphene was pretreated by thermal reflux using 20–60 % nitric acid. The pretreated graphene and catalysts were characterized with TPR, TEM, SEM, XRD, XPS and Raman spectroscopy to study the effect of treatment on microstructures of the materials. This work showed that cobalt metal uniformly dispersed on graphene, and with increasing pretreating acid concentration, surface defects increased and the cobalt particle size decreased, suggesting alleviated agglomeration of cobalt particles on graphene. Pretreating improved the reduction of the catalyst due to the increased defect sites, improved support-metal interaction and cobalt dispersion. Pretreated catalyst yielded better activity, higher C5+, but lower methane selectivity than unpretreated catalyst. Therefore, acid pretreatment of graphene can be an effective approach to modify the microstructure of the material, and can thus enhance the performance of the prepared catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Fischer-Tropsch synthesis: Effect of nitric acid pretreatment on graphene-supported cobalt catalyst
